sub_topic: Quantification of the amount of a substance in a sample using gravimetric analysis
message_1: What is the mass of silver chloride precipitate formed when 25 mL of 0.1 M silver nitrate solution reacts completely with 50 mL of 0.05 M hydrochloric acid solution? Use gravimetric analysis to determine the amount of silver chloride formed.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will first write the balanced chemical equation for the reaction between silver nitrate (AgNO3) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) to form silver chloride (AgCl) precipitate and nitric acid (HNO3).

AgNO3(aq) + HCl(aq) → AgCl(s) + HNO3(aq)

Now, we will determine the limiting reactant by comparing the moles of AgNO3 and HCl.

Moles of AgNO3 = (Volume of AgNO3 solution) × (Concentration of AgNO3)
Moles of AgNO3 = (25 mL) × (0.1 mol/L)
Moles of AgNO3 = 0.0025 mol

Moles of HCl = (Volume of HCl solution) × (Concentration of HCl)
Moles of HCl = (50 mL) × (0.05 mol/L)
Moles of HCl = 0.0025 mol

The stoichiometry of the reaction is 1:1, so we can see that both reactants have the same number of moles. Therefore, both reactants will be completely consumed in the reaction, and there is no limiting reactant.

Now, we can calculate the moles of AgCl formed, which will be equal to the moles of AgNO3 or HCl since the stoichiometry is 1:1.

Moles of AgCl = Moles of AgNO3 = Moles of HCl = 0.0025 mol

Finally, we can calculate the mass of AgCl formed using its molar mass (Ag = 107.87 g/mol, Cl = 35.45 g/mol).

Molar mass of AgCl = 107.87 g/mol + 35.45 g/mol = 143.32 g/mol

Mass of AgCl = (Moles of AgCl) × (Molar mass of AgCl)
Mass of AgCl = (0.0025 mol) × (143.32 g/mol)
Mass of AgCl = 0.3583 g

So, the mass of silver chloride precipitate formed is approximately 0.3583 grams.
